comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: Should be "K. F. Shah", as he appears several other times in the Bain Collection. I am having difficulty finding any non-Bain biographical sources on him, though.

comment.author: 62895879@N00
comment._content:
Correct: should be Shah.  

From A Chinese student publication from 1914: He was a foreign minister from China.  Earlier a student at Columbia University.  Arrived in New York on his way to Washington DC, with his wife, five children and sixteen servants.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
76016463@N00
comment._content: He is Kai Fu Shah (Xia Xiefu), and had been China's Consul General in New York from 1903 to 1908. During that period, he was mentioned regularly in the New York newspapers. In 1914, he arrived in Washington, via New York, as the first envoy to the U.S. of the newly recognized Chinese Republic, and this seems to be the press photo opportunity of April 14, 1914 on the occasion (in Washington) of the presentation of his credentials as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary, Chinese Legation, to the State Department. www.state.gov/s/cpr/91588.htm There are multiple photos from this event in the LOC"s Harris & Ewing collection: www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=kai%20fu%20shah This shot was taken by the Clinedinst Studio of Washington, D.C., a prominent studio so ubiquitous in its Federal Government portraits and subjects that it was sometimes referred to as the Court Photographer of Washington. 19thcenturybaltimore.wordpress.com/2010/07/06/barnett-m-c...

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: bior, dhelling01, swanq, and artolog: Thanks for providing us with correct information for Shah.  We will correct our data next time we update.
